title: 5 billion people will be unable to access health care in 2030, according to the World Health Organization
text:
Countries that aren't investing enough in primary healthcare could hold back global progress and mean that 5 billion people will be unable to receive basic health care in 2030, according to the World Health Organization.

If governments choose to increase annual spending on primary health care by $200 billion a year, they can save up to 60 million lives in low and middle-income countries and increase life expectancy by 3.7 years by 2030.

Read more: Five patients die every minute from incorrect medical treatment, according to the World Health Organization

The report published by WHO claims that primary health care can be scaled up using domestic resources — either by reallocating spending to focus on primary health care or by increasing spending on health in general. It also recommends countries to invest at least 1% of their GDP "to close the glaring coverage gaps and meet health targets agreed in 2015".

WHO maintains that most countries are currently drastically underinvesting in primary health causes. It also claims that for the poorest countries, which include many affected by conflict, assistance from the outside must continue.

Read more: Doctor burnout hits an all-time high with 79% of primary care physicians suffering from workplace stress

Globally, $7.5 trillion is already spent on health care but it barely covers half the world's population. Additionally, nearly 925 million people have to shed 10% of their household income on healthcare alone.

"If we are really serious about achieving universal health coverage and improving people's lives, we must get serious about primary health care," says Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-General. "That means providing essential health services like immunization, antenatal care, healthy lifestyle advice as close to home as possible —and making sure people do not have to pay for this care out of their own pockets."
description: By investing $200 billion into primary health care, governments can save up to 60 million lives in low and middle-income countries.
